habitat_description:
The range extends along coastal habitats of the northern Gulf of Mexico, Texas, and Florida into the Atlantic coast to northern Cuba. Populations of Florida include reports from the Florida Keys (Lawson et al. 1991; Schwartz and Henderson 1991). In particular, subspecies clarkia occurs nearby Corpus Christy along the Gulf Coast of Texas, and in Levy County, Florida. This subspecies shares a significant portion of the region with subspecies compressicauda, extending north into estuarine situations in Pinellas County (Natureserve.org). In contrast, the populations in the south of Florida occupy buttonwood and red mangrove swamps, as well as saline offshore islands (Tennant 1997). 

This species burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, and leaf litter. The habitat is primarily characterized by bays, lagoons, tidal rivers, scrub-shrub wetland, herbaceous wetland, and tidal shores (Natureserve.org). Preferred estuarine situations include salt marshes and coastal brackish marshes vegetated by Spartine, Juncus, and Salicornia. While inland freshwater marshes that include sedges, naiads, and arrowheads are visited less frequently by this species (Dundee and Rossman 1989; Ernst and Ernst 2003; Werler and Dixon 2000). The burrows of fiddler crabs, muskrats, and crayfish represent burrowing/cover opportunities where available. This species is often found under logs, rocks, and ground cover (Dundee and Rossman 1989; Schwartz and Henderson 1991; Tennant 1997).

SE	-Estuarine situations of salt marshes and coastal brackish marshes that are vegetated by Spartine, Juncus, and Salicornia are preferred over sites vegetated by sedges, arrowheads, and naiads.
